summary: Email chain between an Assistant U.S. Attorney and an FBI forensic examiner discussing the status of evidence processing in the Epstein case, focusing on missing files, duplicate folders, and devices requiring hardware recovery. The document reveals ongoing evidence management challenges in 2020.

persons.name: Assistant U.S. Attorney
persons.role: Assistant U.S. Attorney Southern District of New York
persons.context: Prosecutor following up on evidence status, asking specific questions about missing item NYC027913, duplicate folders, and zero-byte files in the Epstein evidence processing.

connections.description: Working relationship between prosecutor and forensic examiner regarding evidence processing in the Epstein case, with the attorney requesting status updates and the examiner providing technical responses.

events.title: Evidence Status Update
events.description: FBI forensic examiner M responds to questions about Epstein evidence, indicating final items were given to another person for delivery and addressing issues with duplicate folders and missing files.

events.title: Evidence Spreadsheet Update
events.description: FBI forensic examiner provides updated spreadsheet of Epstein evidence with color coding, indicating some items will take another day or two to process.

keyFacts: Evidence processing for the Epstein case was still ongoing in July-August 2020, with forensic examiners working on device recovery and file extraction.
Item NYC027913 was identified as missing from evidence materials despite being listed as provided on July 23, 2020.
Approximately 71,000 documents in the initial seven devices were zero-byte (empty) files, which the forensic examiner stated was not unusual for recovery software.
Some devices (highlighted in gray on the spreadsheet) required hardware recovery due to physical failures, including 2 servers with multiple drives that were physically broken.
The email chain shows detailed coordination between prosecutors and FBI forensic examiners about technical aspects of evidence processing, including duplicate folders and file verification.
